Question_1.Context: Mucin 1 (MUC1) is a transmembrane glycoprotein that is normally expressed on the apical surface of epithelial cells and has roles in cell signaling and anti-adhesion properties. In certain malignancies, such as pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, a dysregulation of the glycosylation pattern of normal MUC1 reveals novel cancer-specific epitopes (MUC1-CE).
Question_1.Question: What is the role of MUC1 in normal epithelial cells?
Question_1.Source: Mucin 1 (MUC1) is a transmembrane glycoprotein that is normally expressed on the apical surface of epithelial cells and has a role in cell signalling and anti-adhesion properties.

Question_2.Context: In epithelial malignancies, such as pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, a dysregulation of the glycosylation pattern of normal MUC1 reveals novel cancer-specific epitopes (MUC1-CE).
Question_2.Question: What change in MUC1 is associated with epithelial malignancies like pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma?
Question_2.B: Dysregulation of glycosylation pattern revealing MUC1-CE
Question_2.D: Loss of transmembrane domain of MUC1
Question_2.Source: In epithelial malignancies such as PDAC, a dysregulation of the glycosylation pattern of normal MUC1 reveals novel cancer-specific epitopes (MUC1-CE).

Question_3.Context: Several studies have shown that MUC1-CE is expressed in over 90% of pancreatic cancers. Expression of MUC1-CE has also been linked with chemoresistance and disease progression.
Question_3.Question: What is the significance of MUC1-CE expression in pancreatic cancers?
Question_3.A: It is underexpressed in most cases
Question_3.B: It is linked with increased sensitivity to chemotherapy
Question_3.C: It is expressed in over 90% of cases and linked with chemoresistance
Question_3.D: It has no impact on disease progression
Question_3.Source: Several studies have shown that MUC1-CE is expressed in over 90% of pancreatic cancers. Expression of MUC1-CE has also been linked with chemoresistance and disease progression.

Question_4.Context: Radiolabelling of antibodies to a therapeutic radionuclide which emits alpha particles, beta particles or auger electrons has been shown to elicit a cytotoxic effect.
Question_4.Question: What is the outcome of radiolabelling antibodies with radionuclides that emit alpha particles, beta particles, or auger electrons?
Question_4.Source: Radiolabelling of these antibodies to a therapeutic radionuclide which emits alpha particles, beta particles or auger electrons has been shown to elicit a cytotoxic effect.

Question_5.Context: Lutetium-177 (Lu-177) is a beta-emitting radionuclide that has established its role in clinical nuclear medicine due to its optimal half-life and medium range beta-emissions, which provide cross-fire effects to target solid tumours.
Question_5.Question: Why is Lutetium-177 (Lu-177) used in clinical nuclear medicine for targeting solid tumours?
Question_5.A: Due to its short half-life and high-energy gamma emissions
Question_5.B: Because it emits alpha particles with a very short range
Question_5.C: Due to its optimal half-life and medium range beta-emissions
Question_5.D: Because it is a stable isotope with no radioactive emissions
Question_5.Source: As a beta-emitting radionuclide, Lutetium-177 (Lu-177) has established itself within the clinical nuclear medicine field due to its increasing availability, 6.7 day half-life allowing for optimal tumour diffusion before decay, and medium range beta-emissions which provide cross-fire effects to target solid tumours.

Question_6.Context: The process of conjugation involves attaching a bifunctional chelator to an antibody, which can then be used for subsequent radiolabelling.
Question_6.Question: What is the purpose of conjugating a bifunctional chelator to an antibody in the context of radiopharmaceutical development?
Question_6.A: To decrease the immunogenicity of the antibody
Question_6.B: To enable the antibody to cross the blood-brain barrier
Question_6.C: To facilitate subsequent radiolabelling of the antibody
Question_6.D: To increase the half-life of the antibody in the bloodstream
Question_6.Source: Conjugation of p‑SCN‑Bn‑DOTA to C595 antibody A 40-fold molar excess of p-SCN-Bn-DOTA was incubated with C595 antibody for 2 h in a 0.1 M sodium bicarbonate buffer (pH 8.5) at 37 °C in a ThermoMixer® (Eppendorf, Germany) at 700 RPM. Unbound DOTA was removed through a purification process using 50 kDa Amicon® centrifugal filter units.

Question_7.Context: In vitro experiments can be used to assess the binding affinity of a radioimmunoconjugate to cancer cells, which is crucial for determining its potential efficacy as a therapeutic agent.
Question_7.Question: What is the significance of assessing the binding affinity of a radioimmunoconjugate to cancer cells in vitro?
Question_7.A: To determine the nutritional requirements of the cancer cells
Question_7.B: To measure the metabolic rate of the cancer cells
Question_7.C: To evaluate the potential efficacy of the radioimmunoconjugate as a therapeutic agent
Question_7.D: To assess the ability of cancer cells to resist apoptosis
Question_7.Source: All cell lines demonstrated a linear relationship between the concentration of [177Lu] Lu-DOTA-C595 added and bound radioactivity. Binding of [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-C595 was significantly greater to PANC-1 cells than all other cell lines at concentrations of 50, 200, 300 and 400 nM.

Question_8.Context: The internalisation assay is used to evaluate the rate at which a radioimmunoconjugate is taken up by cancer cells, which can influence the overall toxicity of the therapy.
Question_8.Question: Why is the internalisation rate of a radioimmunoconjugate by cancer cells important?
Question_8.A: It determines the speed at which cancer cells can replicate
Question_8.B: It influences the overall toxicity of the therapy to the cancer cells
Question_8.C: It affects the ability of cancer cells to migrate and invade other tissues
Question_8.D: It indicates the energy production rate of cancer cells
Question_8.Source: The internalised fraction of activity demonstrated rapid increases in PANC-1 cells as time progressed, whilst all other cell lines demonstrated lower levels of internalisation with only mild increases in internalised counts over time.

Question_9.Context: The clonogenic assay is a method used to evaluate the cytotoxic effects of a treatment by assessing the ability of a single cell to grow into a colony.
Question_9.Question: What is the purpose of a clonogenic assay in the context of evaluating a radioimmunoconjugate's cytotoxic effects?
Question_9.A: To determine the ability of a single cell to grow into a colony after treatment
Question_9.B: To measure the oxygen consumption of treated cells
Question_9.C: To assess the rate of DNA replication in treated cells
Question_9.D: To evaluate the membrane potential of treated cells
Question_9.Source: To evaluate the cytotoxic effects of [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-C595, a clonogenic assay was performed using PANC-1 and AsPC-1 cell lines.

Question_10.Context: γH2AX foci staining is a technique used to detect double-strand DNA breaks, which are indicative of DNA damage within cells.
Question_10.Question: What does the detection of γH2AX foci in cells indicate?
Question_10.Source: Staining of γH2AX foci was used as a marker for detecting double strand DNA breaks.
